title: Inheritance tax: UK's most hated tax lives on
text:
Inheritance tax: UK's most hated tax lives on Inheritance tax: UK's most hated tax lives on CHANCELLOR George Osborne’s move to allow families to pass on estates worth up to £1million free of inheritance tax (IHT) was warmly received but is far less generous than it first seems. PUBLISHED: 16:23, Sun, Jul 12, 2015 | UPDATED: 16:37, Sun, Jul 12, 2015 PA George Osborne delivers his Budget statement to the House of Commons 
The changes to the UK’s most hated tax, announced in last week’s emergency Budget, are complicated, will only apply to the main family home and will take several years to come fully into effect. 
Any apparent savings may be offset by sleight of hand elsewhere. 
So could your family still end up paying death duty? 
Last Wednesday, Osborne claimed that homeowners can now pass on up to £1million to their children or grandchildren, free of IHT, but it is not as simple as that. 
The new rules will not apply to everybody and rising house prices could still drag more and more families into the net. 
Currently, IHT is paid at a whopping 40 per cent on all inherited assets worth more than £325,000. 
So somebody whose estate totalled £425,000 would incur IHT on £100,000, landing their loved ones a huge £40,000 bill. 
Married couples and civil partners are in a better position because they can inherit each other’s allowance, so £650,000 in total. 
There will be a new transferable amount of £175,000 on top for each parent leaving their home to their children and grandchildren. 
But while the Chancellor is giving with one hand, he is taking away with the other. 
One reason so many ordinary middle-class families now pay IHT is that the £325,000 threshold has been frozen since 2009, while house prices have risen sharply in that time, especially in London and the South-East. Related articles At last, victory for the Daily Express crusade 
Patricia Mock, tax director at accountancy giant Deloitte says: “If the nil-rate band had risen in line with the consumer prices index it would now be worth around £378,000.” 
It will continue to be frozen until 2021, which will whittle away at its usefulness in real terms. 
Sean McCann, chartered financial planner at NFU Mutual, says: “Inflation and future house-price growth will steadily erode the value of this tax break.” 
The Chancellor is also taking his time over phasing in his extra £175,000 tax-free nil-rate band. 
It will not kick in until the 2017/18 tax year and then at just £100,000. 
It will gradually increase until it finally reaches £175,000 in 2020/21. 
At that point, it will be indexed to rise in line with the consumer prices index. 
He has pledged to introduce new rules to ensure that those who downsize their property in later life do not lose out. 
Worse, many families will not see any benefit at all. 
Julie Hutchison, savings and tax expert at Standard Life, says the new threshold applies only to those with children or grandchildren. 
“It will not increase your allowance if you are supporting nephews, nieces, children of friends and so on.” 
The tax break will apply only to the main family residence. 
Also, the full £1million will not apply to cohabiting couples, because only married couples and civil partners can transfer their allowance to each other on death. 
For estates worth more than £2million, the additional IHT allowance will be gradually clawed back. 
Hutchison says the new allowance complicates what was already a tricky tax to understand. 
She suggests that families need to take expert advice if they fear they will still be hit by IHT. 
"Careful planning is needed to check whether you need to update your will to accommodate this measure.” 
Last week’s Budget did not spell the end of IHT. 
In fact, the annual tax take will continue to rise, if at a slower pace than before. 
HM Revenue & Customs raised £3.4billion from IHT in 2013/14. By 2020/21, that is forecast to collect £5.8million. 
Rachael Griffin, financial planning expert at Old Mutual Wealth, says: “Increasing the IHT allowance in line with house price inflation would have been a more robust and cleaner solution.” 
Scrapping it altogether would have been cleaner still, but that will have to wait for a future Budget. 
Until then, Britain’s most hated tax lives on. Related articles
